content:
Getting back into swimming is a great goal! Improving your technique can make a huge difference in your efficiency, endurance, and overall enjoyment of the sport. Here are some tips to help you refine your swimming technique:

1. **Focus on body position**: Maintain a horizontal body position, with your ears, shoulders, and hips aligned. This will help you cut through the water with less resistance. Imagine a straight line from head to heels.
2. **Streamline your kick**: Keep your legs relaxed and bent, with your feet together. Avoid bending your knees or ankles, as this creates drag. Instead, focus on a smooth, alternating kick that originates from your hips.
3. **Use your hips**: Rotate your hips with each stroke, keeping your shoulders and head still. This helps generate power and maintains a smooth, efficient stroke.
4. **Improve your arm technique**:
	* **Freestyle**: Keep your arms relaxed, with your hands entering the water with your fingers together and your elbows high. Use a circular motion, pulling back towards your hips, and then recovering your arms forward.
	* **Backstroke**: Keep your arms straight, with your hands entering the water with your palms facing upwards. Use a smooth, sweeping motion, keeping your elbows high and your shoulders relaxed.
5. **Work on your hand entry**: Enter the water with your hands at a 45-degree angle, with your fingers together and your thumbs down. This helps reduce drag and promotes a smooth, efficient stroke.
6. **Practice drills**: Incorporate drills into your swim sessions to focus on specific techniques, such as:
	* Kicking drills (e.g., flutter kick, frog kick)
	* Arm drills (e.g., catch-up drill, fingertip drill)
	* Body position drills (e.g., kicking on your side, swimming with a snorkel)
7. **Use visualization techniques**: Visualize yourself swimming efficiently, focusing on perfect technique. Imagine yourself gliding through the water, with each stroke building upon the last.
8. **Get feedback**: Work with a swim coach, instructor, or experienced swimmer to provide feedback on your technique. They can identify areas for improvement and offer personalized tips.
9. **Practice regularly**: Consistency is key when it comes to improving your technique. Aim to swim at least 2-3 times a week, with a mix of technique-focused sessions and endurance swims.
10. **Focus on relaxation**: Swimming is all about efficiency, so try to relax and conserve energy. Avoid tension in your shoulders, arms, and legs, as this can lead to fatigue and poor technique.

Remember, improving your technique takes time and practice. Be patient, stay consistent, and you'll see improvements over time. Good luck, and have fun getting back into swimming!
